articles.headline: Hospitals Fear They’ll Bear Brunt of Medicare Cuts
articles.snippet: Consensus is building around the idea that the largest Medicare savings should come from institutional providers of care.
articles.abstract: Consensus is building around the idea that the largest Medicare savings should come from institutional providers of care.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama and Congress try to thrash out a budget deal, the question is not whether they will squeeze money out of Medicare, but how much and who will bear the brunt of the cuts.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: F.T.C. Opens an Inquiry Into Data Brokers
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission is looking at nine companies that collect, sell or analyze information about consumers.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission is looking at nine companies that collect, sell or analyze information about consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s getting tougher to be a data broker.

articles.headline: U.S. Inquiry of Google Is Expected to Press On
articles.snippet: Google must submit a plan in January to change its practices to avoid a fine or finding of wrongdoing, Europe’s top antitrust enforcer said.
articles.abstract: Google must submit a plan in January to change its practices to avoid a fine or finding of wrongdoing, Europe’s top antitrust enforcer said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission is unlikely to finish until January its investigation into whether Google abused its power in the search market, people briefed on the investigation said on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and James Kanter

articles.headline: Facebook Responds to Anger Over Proposed Instagram Changes
articles.snippet: Instagram users have been complaining about Facebook’s plan to build advertising into the service. In response, the company said it would make changes to the plan.
articles.abstract: Instagram users have been complaining about Facebook’s plan to build advertising into the service. In response, the company said it would make changes to the plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeremy Pinnix, an app developer in Spring Hill, Tenn., has been a regular user of the photo-sharing service Instagram since it was introduced in 2010, posting pictures of his family, local scenery and favorite moments.

articles.headline: Goodbye, Government, Under Either Fiscal Plan
articles.snippet: The contemplated cuts in discretionary spending would make the federal government little more than a heavily armed pension plan with a health insurer on the side.
articles.abstract: The contemplated cuts in discretionary spending would make the federal government little more than a heavily armed pension plan with a health insurer on the side.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Obama and Speaker John Boehner negotiate to resolve the looming fiscal crisis, Americans might be forgiven for believing that the nation’s problems would be solved if they could only agree on whether to raise $1.2 trillion or $1 trillion in new taxes over the next 10 years, or whether they should cut $850 billion rather than $1.2 trillion more in government spending.

articles.headline: Rubble and Despair of War Redefine Syria Jewel
articles.snippet: Aleppo, Syria’s largest city and the bloodied stage for a battle now running into its sixth month, is administered by no one and slipping into disaster.
articles.abstract: Aleppo, Syria’s largest city and the bloodied stage for a battle now running into its sixth month, is administered by no one and slipping into disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALEPPO, Syria — Inside the classrooms where they once studied, the boys darted like a pack. Their banging and clanking could be heard for a city block.

articles.headline: Panel Assails Role of State Department in Benghazi Attack
articles.snippet: An inquiry into the attack on the American diplomatic mission in Libya criticized the State Department for a lack of seasoned security personnel and for ignoring requests for more guards.
articles.abstract: An inquiry into the attack on the American diplomatic mission in Libya criticized the State Department for a lack of seasoned security personnel and for ignoring requests for more guards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An independent inquiry into the attack on the United States diplomatic mission in Libya that killed four Americans on Sept. 11 sharply criticized the State Department for a lack of seasoned security personnel and for relying on untested local militias to safeguard the compound, according to a report by the panel made public on Tuesday night.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Obama Facing Critical Choice After Shooting
articles.snippet: Hurricane Sandy, last month’s Latino turnout for Democrats and now the Newtown, Conn., shootings have presented President Obama with many decisions — and openings to make new arguments.
articles.abstract: Hurricane Sandy, last month’s Latino turnout for Democrats and now the Newtown, Conn., shootings have presented President Obama with many decisions — and openings to make new arguments.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, the massacre of schoolchildren in Connecticut has upended standard political calculations and has presented a choice that goes to the heart of his approach to governance, not just on guns but also on issues like climate change, immigration and even taxes.

articles.headline: Broad Gun Control Efforts Introduced in Wake of Shooting
articles.snippet: The first concrete responses to the shootings in Newtown, Conn., began emerging Tuesday, as state leaders, corporations and the White House pointed to gun control measures.
articles.abstract: The first concrete responses to the shootings in Newtown, Conn., began emerging Tuesday, as state leaders, corporations and the White House pointed to gun control measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first concrete responses to the massacre in Newtown, Conn., began emerging on Tuesday, as state leaders proposed measures to curb gun violence, corporations distanced themselves from an event that has traumatized the nation and the White House pointed to gun control measures that President Obama would champion in the months ahead.

articles.headline: BBC’s Leaders Faulted as Lax in Handling Sex Abuse Crisis
articles.snippet: An exhaustive report strongly criticized the decisions that prompted the BBC to cancel a broadcast in 2011 that would have exposed decades of sexual abuse by Jimmy Savile.
articles.abstract: An exhaustive report strongly criticized the decisions that prompted the BBC to cancel a broadcast in 2011 that would have exposed decades of sexual abuse by Jimmy Savile.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Lax leadership hampered by “rigid management chains” left the British Broadcasting Corporation “completely incapable” of dealing with the sexual abuse crisis that has shaken the network, in the words of an exhaustive report released Wednesday.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Treasury to Sell G.M. Stake Within 15 Months
articles.snippet: An end to “Government Motors”: The Treasury Department plans to sell off its entire 32 percent stake in the auto maker, eliminating another reminder of the bailouts precipitated by the financial crash of 2008.
articles.abstract: An end to “Government Motors”: The Treasury Department plans to sell off its entire 32 percent stake in the auto maker, eliminating another reminder of the bailouts precipitated by the financial crash of 2008.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Knight Capital and Getco to Merge
articles.snippet: The $1.4 billion deal will give Getco, the privately held high-speed trading firm, a public listing in a new holding company.
articles.abstract: The $1.4 billion deal will give Getco, the privately held high-speed trading firm, a public listing in a new holding company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Knight Capital, the stock market-making firm that nearly collapsed last summer after a $440 million trading glitch, has reached an agreement to merge with Getco, the Chicago-based high-speed trading firm.

articles.headline: A Conservative Whose Supreme Court Bid Set the Senate Afire
articles.snippet: Judge Bork’s 1987 nomination to the Supreme Court was rejected by the Senate, not on qualifications but on judicial philosophy and temperament. He died Wednesday at 85.
articles.abstract: Judge Bork’s 1987 nomination to the Supreme Court was rejected by the Senate, not on qualifications but on judicial philosophy and temperament. He died Wednesday at 85.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert H. Bork, a former solicitor general, federal judge and conservative legal theorist whose 1987 nomination to the United States Supreme Court was rejected by the Senate in a historic political battle whose impact is still being felt, died on Wednesday in Arlington, Va. He was 85.
